title: 108_s822
content: The "Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2003" may be cited as the short title. It establishes the Child Care Business Loan Program. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans with restrictions and limitations. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to authorize loans for small, non-profit child care businesses, subject to approval by the Administration and meeting eligibility requirements. The Small Business Administration shall submit reports on the implementation of the program for financial assistance to non-profit child care businesses to the Senate and House committees every 6 months. The Small Business Administration will provide reports on the implementation of financial assistance program for non-profit child care businesses to the Senate and House committees every 6 months. The report will include the program implementation date, rules issuance date, and details on the number and amount of loans applied for, approved, and disbursed in the previous 6 months. Additionally, the Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on child care small business loans by March 31, 2006. The Comptroller General of the United States will submit a report on child care small business loans to the Senate and House committees, containing information gathered during the first 2 years of the loan program. This includes an evaluation of the timeliness of the program's implementation and its effectiveness. The report will include details on the implementation and participation of Certified Development Companies, lenders, and small businesses in the loan program, as well as how the program was marketed. It will also provide information on the number of child care small businesses that applied for and were approved for loans under the program. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will issue final rules within 120 days of the enactment of the Act to implement the loan program. The rules will cover details such as the number of businesses in each state, total loan amounts, and average loan amounts and terms. The Administrator of the Small Business Administration will issue final rules within 120 days of the enactment of the Act to implement the loan program authorized by section 502(b)(1)(B) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The amendments made by this section will be in effect until September 30, 2006, applying to all loans made during the specified period.
